div1.p: Hench expresses great interest in receiving copies of correspondence by Moran and Kean.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Harry Clemons, May 7, 1940
div1.opener:
May 7, 1940
Mr. Harry Clemons, Librarian
University of Virginia
Alderman Library
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Clemons:
div1.p:
I do appreciate so much your lending me the book “Walter Reed and Yellow
Fever” by Dr. Howard A. Kelly, at the request of Mr. John J. Moran. I had a most
interesting time, spending ten days with Mr. Moran in Havana, and meeting other
survivors of the yellow fever experiments. Among other things, I found that the
Cuban government has erected a memorial at the wrong place, and what is labeled
by them “Camp Lazear” is not Camp Lazear at all. We finally located the real
Camp Lazear, and I collected a certain amount of documentary and other evidence
which I have already submitted to the Cuban government. I think we convinced them,
although not without a struggle. I got considerable more dope on the yellow fever
story, part of it inspiring and delightful, and part of it sordid. Naturally,
I shall not emphasize the latter when I write the story up.

I shall be interested to have the photoprint copy of General Kean's letter
and also of Mr. Moran's. I am sure Mr. Moran would let me have one, as he was
amazingly kind in handing over all kinds of material, some of which he insists that
I keep, against my better judgment. I have already had some correspondence with
General Kean and have an appointment to see him in June.

Incidentally, I hope to being my family on a visit to my brother, Dr. A. L.
Hench, of the English Department, University of Virginia. I hope to pay my respects
to you and to thank you in person at that time.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
